column1: There is a sumptuous variety about the New England weather that compels the stranger's admiration—and regret. The weather is always doing something there; always attending strictly to business; always getting up new designs and trying them on the people to see how they will go. But it gets through more business in spring than in any other season. In the spring I have counted one hundred and thirty-six different kinds of weather within four and twenty hours. It was I who made the fame and fortune of the man who had that marvelous collection of weather on exhibition at the Centennial
column2: which so astounded the foreigners. He was going to travel around the world and get specimens from all climes. I said
column3: "Don't do it; just come to New England on a favorable spring day." I told him what we could do in the way of style
column7: and he made his collection in four days.
